Result

If you have all the pre-requisite complete along with the above steps, we should readily be able to do the API Proxy transports, API Provider transports from source subaccounts to destination subaccounts. Once you click transport from the source, it should create a transport ID and a transport request that can be seen in Cloud TMS with the API details.

entry.title: Source-Side Filtering vs. Dynamic Topics &Filtering with SAP Advanced Event Mesh and ASAPIO Addon
entry.content:
As more and more organizations modernize their integration landscapes whether they are SAP or non-SAP eco systems, Event-Driven Architecture (EDA) is becoming an essential approach to achieving real-time, scalable, and loosely coupled data exchange. Traditional master data distribution—often based on scheduled or API-driven replication—can no longer keep up with the dynamic needs of digital ecosystems that demand instant synchronization across hybrid SAP and non-SAP environments.

By leveraging SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM), and ERP event-on for AEM, enterprises can easily shift toward event-based master data distribution to ensure that updates in systems of records are propagated intelligently, only where and when they are needed. This trend not only reduces system load and redundancy but also enables fine-grained control through mechanisms like source-side filtering and dynamic topic filtering within brokers, which together make EDA a cornerstone for next-generation integration strategies.

Three years ago, I shared a blog on the SAP Event Enablement Add-On for SAP Event Mesh. Since then, SAP Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) has rapidly gained growth as an enterprise-grade event broker with the capability to connect applications, data, and devices across diverse landscapes. 

In this blog, I would like to revisit the ASAPIO Add-On, specifically in the context of integration SAP Advanced Event Mesh. While the add-on continues to be powered by ASAPIO technology, its usage patterns and relevance have evolved alongside AEM's growing adoption. Most of the functionalities are similar but with the ability to build custom payloads and to connect to AEM, it unlocks the value of moving data in real-time from large to very large use cases.

@Benedikt_Sprung   has already published an excellent step-by-step guide on setting up and using the add-on with AEM. Instead of duplicating that content, my focus here will be on a key design consideration: the filtering options available with the add-on and AEM and how they can be applied effectively in real-world scenarios. 

 

Why filtering matters?

Typically, Event-driven architectures (EDA) topics define how events are organized. The way we design and manage topics has a profound impact on scalability, governance, and maintainability. 

In the context of SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh (AEM) with ASAPIO add-on, two patterns come into discussion with event filtering: source-side filtering (on sender SAP applications) and Dynamic Topics & Filtering (within AEM brokers).

This post explores the difference between these two approaches, when to use each, and how AEM enables more intelligent event distribution in enterprise landscapes.

 

Option 1: Source-Side Filtering on Event Producer

Source-Side filtering usually means the producer (event source) decides dynamically at publish time whether an event should be triggered. Often, a filter based on payload data will be applied to the event liberation.

With ASAPIO add-on, you can use a check function module in header attributes to filter on attributes of the Business Object. For example, you can add the Attribute ID to your Header Attribute customizing in event add-on for ERP: BOR_ATTRIBUTE_<BOR Attribute from SWO1>

 

In this case, only the material data with material group 004 will be triggered. The event broker (AEM) will not receive any data outside of material group 004.

Option 2: Dynamic Topics & Filtering on Event Broker

With this option, the producer (event source) decides at publish time which topic an event should be sent to. Often, topic names are built using runtime data (e.g., customer ID, region, product type).

With ASAPIO add-on, you can set up dynamic topics easily with Field Mapping. It helps you define different layers of the topics and make dynamic filtering easier later during consumption.

 

Based on event context, events can be published to different topics into SAP AEM. Consumers then subscribe only to the events they care about. In above example, topics are built dynamically with the Sales Org ID. If a consumer wants all the data of Sales Order update of Org 1000, it can subscribe to topic /UPDATE/V1/JSON/sap-bo-event/ERD100/1000/BUS2032/>.

In this case, all events are still published to the broker but they can be sorted/routef based on the structure of the topics.

 

When to Use Which?

Source Side Filtering typically works well when consumers are highly specialized and fixed. You don't expect new applications to be added in the future. And in the case when broker load and network traffic is a concern, you can use this option to reduce overhead.

In contrast, dynamic topics & filtering helps you operate at enterprise scale (hundreds of apps, regions, business lines). You want to use this option when you want producers to stay simple and consumers to self-serve. with SAP AEM, it can support very large scale use cases. Using this option will help you have better governance and discoverability on events. 

Dynamic topics & filtering is recommended in most of the use cases as it supports better scalability and flexibility in an EDA integration. To support this option, SAP AEM has its Smart Topics feature to organize event topics. The Topic Taxonomy can be described with none+verb+properties. AEM relies on hierarchical topic structures(using  “/” separators) to enable dynamic routing, filtering, and fine-tuned subscriptions.

An Example of master data event topics could be:

  • materialmaster / updated / <materialgroup> / <materialtype>
  • materialmaster / created / <materialgroup> / <materialtype>

With a defined structure, subscribers can filter based on dynamic topics that they are interested in:

This allows flexibility of subscription and allows consumers to self-serve as well.

 

Conclusion and key takeaways

While source-side filtering gives flexibility, it often leads to topic sprawl and tighter coupling. With SAP Integration Suite, Advanced Event Mesh, enterprises can adopt Smart Topics with Dynamic Topics & Filtering — a governance-friendly, scalable way to manage events. This approach keeps producers simple and empowers consumers at enterprise scale.

In most of the use cases, master data distribution is a fan-out pattern, in this case Dynamic Topics & Filtering will provide more flexibility to distribute the data based on needs without tight coupling with producers. Below is a reference architecture for a fan-out scenario and with dynamic topic filtering and multiple integration options, you will be able to easily send to the relevant data to consumers.

 

Happy Eventing!!

SAP Integration Suite SAP S/4HANA Event-driven architecture

entry.title: Generic XI Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline
entry.content:
With the latest version update 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration package, we have added a generic XI outbound processing flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI. It's shipped with the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound. You can use the generic XI outbound flow for both asynchronous as well as synchronous communication using the XI message protocol. See Introducing a new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages.

Intro

The generic XI outbound processing flow is actually not replacing the scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07), it is an additional step (Step 08) in the rows of pipeline steps for handling the connection to receiver systems using the XI protocol. So, in step 07 you define your scenario-specific mappings and then call step 08 via ProcessDirect adapter. Step 08 acts then as XI receiver channel to dynamically connecting to the backend systems.

This new feature was done per customer's request to standardize and ease the configuration of XI outbound scenarios. With this, you are able to dynamically connect to the backend, set monitoring headers in a common way, and store adapter connectivity logic in one place.

It was also done because we quite often noticed that the XI receiver adapter was wrongly setup in terms of delivery assurance. In the new XI outbound processing integration flow, the delivery assurance in the receiver adapter is properly setup using the UniqueID header which is passed from the pipeline. By default, the UniqueID equals the Message Processing Log ID of the generic outbound processing flow (Step 06) which takes care of dispatching messages to the scenario-specific flows and eventually restarting failed messages. You also have the option to modify the UniqueID header in the scenario-specific outbound flow if you prefer to use a unique ID from the message payload. In any case, a unique ID will be automatically used by the XI receiver adapter ensuring Exactly Once delivery.

Configuration Options

As said, you dynamically configure the XI receiver adapter parameters and the XI header attributes during runtime. For this, different options are supported as outlined in the XI Receiver Adapter help documentation. Combining the options is also supported.

  • You can create and maintain message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow (Step 07).
  • You can create and maintain the parameters in the Partner Directory.
  • You can configure the externalized parameters of the generic XI outbound integration flow (Step 08).

We distinguish between XI connection parameters and XI message headers (scenario related).

  • Because XI headers are scenario-specific (e.g. Service Interface name), you would configure them either as message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow or as string parameters in the Partner Directory for the partner ID representing the configuration scenario.
  • The configuration of connection parameters depends on your chosen approach. You may define receiver-specific XI outbound flows by copying the Cloud Integration Pipeline – Generic Outbound package. This allows you to create an individual XI Step 08 flow for each XI receiver and in this case, you would configure the connection parameters as externalized parameters of the copied generic XI outbound integration flow. Otherwise, if you used one single generic XI outbound integration flow across all scenarios and all receivers, you would maintain string parameters in the Partner Directory for the partner ID representing the business component or configure them as message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow Step 07.

Sample Scenario

This blog post intends to explain the different options in more detail along sample scenarios. In the Partner Directory, we have setup a configuration scenario of pattern Content-Based-Router with 2 sender systems and 3 receiver systems. On the Alternative Partners tab, we map the sender system names, the sender interface name and the sender interface namespace to our configuration scenario, here CS_PIP_Samples_Scenario_02E. Actually, on the sender side we also use the XI protocol, so those parameters are part of the XI header of the message sent to Cloud Integration. In the generic XI inbound flow we then determine the partner ID of the configuration scenario based on the alternative partner defined.

Each receiver is differently configured to be able to cover all options mentioned above. On tab Binary Parameters, we have uploaded a binary containing the XSLT which is carried out to determine the receivers based on XPath conditions.

In the XSLT, you can see that for the 3 receivers we call different scenario-specific outbound processing flows.

Option 1: Message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow

The first receiver, in our case BS_02E_R1, uses the first option by maintaining message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow. As you can see below, the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific outbound processing flow is the one maintained in the XSLT in case that the supplier equals ABCD and the country equals DE.

In a content modifier step, we have maintained the connection parameters like credential alias, authentication method, proxy type and XI endpoint of the receiver system as well as the XI headers SAP_ReceiverInterface and SAP_ReceiverInterfaceNamespace as message headers. The headers SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline. Optionally, you can override them here. All message headers are then passed to the generic XI outbound flow. For the detailed parameter names, refer to XI Receiver Adapter.

We then call the generic XI outbound flow via ProcessDirect adapter. Here, we need to enter the endpoint of the generic XI outbound flow.

By default, the endpoint of the generic XI outbound flow equals /generic/step08/xi. You can change to your own preferences. We kept the default.

Finally, we sent a sample message to the pipeline. In the message monitor you find all log entries that belong to the same exchanged message. You can filter on the log entries by selecting the Correlation ID link. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc.

By the way, the actual sender and receiver names are BS_02E_S1Q and BS_02E_R1Q, respectively, because we run the scenario on the Quality Assurance environment. Those names are then mapped to alias names which are used within the pipeline, e.g., in the XSLT. See next chapter where we show how to setup the support for different landscape stages for the involved business systems.

 

Option 2: Parameters in the Partner Directory

The second receiver, here BS_02E_R2, uses the second option by maintaining the Partner Directory parameters. The corresponding scenario-specific outbound processing flow has the ProcessDirect endpoint configured as maintained in the XSLT above for the case that the supplier equals EFGH and for any country other than DE. Here, we do not need to create any message headers and we forward the message to the generic XI outbound flow with default endpoint like in the option before.

As mentioned above, you can maintain both in the Partner Directory XI headers and connection parameters. For the connection parameters we need to define a partner ID representing the business system. We need this anyway to map from the actual business system name to the alias name. We actually did this for all systems involved in the configuration scenarios. As an example the screenshot below shows the partner ID with the alias name BS_02E_R2. In the Alternative Partners tab, we map the actual names to the alias depending on the landscape stage, e.g., for QA the actual name is BS_02E_R2Q. If you like to know more about how to setup the support for different landscape stages, check out Landscape Stages.

On the String Parameters tab of the System Alias, we have maintained the XI connection parameters i.e. proxy type, authentication method, credential alias, and XI endpoint of the receiver system. The naming convention is to add the actual system name as suffix to the parameter names. Here, we only did this for the QA landscape, usually you would then also maintain the string parameters for the other landscapes. By the way, this business system alias can be used across different configuration scenarios and hence you can reuse those connection settings. For the detailed parameter names, refer to XI Receiver Adapter.

The XI headers are scenario-specific and hence they are maintained as string parameters of the configuration scenario. For the InterfaceNameDetermination parameter add the receiver system alias as suffix. For the InterfaceNamespaceDetermination parameter add the interface name that you defined before as suffix (the namespace can also be determined dynamically in Step 08 by evaluating an XPath expression against the XML payload; however, this requires that the payload’s namespace matches the namespace of the corresponding Service Interface). The other XI headers SAP_SenderParty, SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface, SAP_ReceiverParty and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline.

When sending a sample message to the pipeline, you can monitor the exchanged message in the message monitor. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc. Here we actually also use a party for the receiver system, see XSLT above.

 

Option 3: Configuring the generic XI outbound integration flow

The third receiver, here BS_02E_R3, uses the third option i.e. an own generic XI outbound integration flow. In this case, we need to create a copy of the generic XI outbound integration flow and configure the connection parameters as externalized parameters of the copied flow. It is important not to directly copy the integration flow but rather copy the standard package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound that we provide on the SAP Accelerator Business Hub. This way, you ensure that the copied integration flow still receives updates if any.

So, in the Discover area of your tenant, search for the package and then select Copy.

In the upcoming dialog, you are informed that the package already exists, so select Create copy.

Then maintain a package suffix, here BS.02ER3 indicating that this is a business system specific package, then select OK. All integration flows of the copied package get the suffix added to their IDs as well.

When switching to the Design area, you should see the copied package.

In the copied package, configure the Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI flow. Before you are able to deploy the flow, you need to change its ProcessDirect endpoint. This needs to be unique across the tenant.

Furthermore, on tab More we configure the XI connection parameters. Note, those are actually default values. They are only applied if not otherwise defined i.e. as message headers or in the Partner Directory. For this receiver, this is not the case so we ensure that those default values are used.

The corresponding scenario-specific outbound processing flow has the ProcessDirect endpoint configured as maintained in the XSLT above for the case that no receiver could be determined, see above.

We do need to at least maintain the XI headers SAP_ReceiverInterface and SAP_ReceiverInterfaceNamespace as message headers. The headers SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline.

In order to call the copied generic XI outbound flow, we need to enter its ProcessDirect endpoint as configured above.

When sending a sample message to the pipeline, you can monitor the exchanged message in the message monitor. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc.

Unfortunately, the copied XI outbound flow name is kept unchanged. You need to scroll down to the Artifacts Details section to see its integration flow ID which contains the suffix.

Hope this helps you set up your XI outbound scenarios using the new generic XI outbound flow of the Cloud Integration Pipeline. If you are missing any XI-specific processing capabilities that would be useful for such a generic XI receiver flow, feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Good to Know

Outbound processing for XI is designed around the XI receiver adapter’s capability to manage Quality of Service at the Integration Flow level. When this processing mode is enabled, you need to explicitly define the Quality of Service in the integration flow by setting the message header SapQualityOfService. The pipeline automatically sets the correct Quality of Service, however you need to ensure that the header SapQualityOfService is added to the allowed headers of the scenario-specific outbound processing flow. Optionally, you can create the message header SapQualityOfService in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow. Right now, the pipeline doesn't support Exactly Once In Order, so for asynchronous communication set the value to ExactlyOnce, for synchronous communication the value equals BestEffort.

Furthermore, the Handled by Integration flow delivery assurance mode allows the outbound connection to be created from a Message End event only. This means that Request-Reply or Send steps cannot be used, and the XI call will always appear as the final processing step in the main integration process. Because of this limitation, it is not possible to set custom headers containing the XI Message ID generated in the receiver XI system for end-to-end tracking. To address this, we recommend adding a Content Modifier in your Step 07 to store custom headers with the XI Message ID and then attach these headers to the message processing log using the script from the Pipeline v2 - Script Collection.

entry.title: Generic IDoc Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline
entry.content:
With the latest version update 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration package, we have added a generic IDoc outbound processing flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for IDoc. It's shipped with the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound. See Introducing a new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages.

Intro

The generic IDoc outbound processing flow does not replace the scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07). Instead, it introduces an additional pipeline step (Step 08) dedicated to managing the IDoc receiver connection. In practical terms, you continue to design your scenario-specific mappings and logic in Step 07, and then hand over the message to Step 08 via a ProcessDirect call. Step 08 then takes over as a standardized IDoc receiver channel, dynamically connecting to backend systems.

This new capability was introduced based on customer feedback, with the goal of simplifying and standardizing IDoc outbound configurations. With it, you can dynamically determine backend connections, apply monitoring headers in a consistent way, and centralize adapter-related configuration in one place. In addition, you can override control record values - similar to what has long been possible in SAP Process Orchestration (options to override any of the control record fields).

Another reason for introducing this step is that we frequently observed misconfigurations of the IDoc receiver adapter, particularly around delivery assurance. In the new IDoc outbound processing flow, delivery assurance is automatically set up correctly by leveraging the UniqueID header passed through the pipeline. By default, this UniqueID corresponds to the Message Processing Log (MPL) ID of the generic outbound dispatcher (Step 06), ensuring reliable restarting of failed messages. If needed, you can also override the UniqueID in your scenario-specific flow - for example, by using a business identifier from the payload. Regardless of the option you choose, the IDoc receiver adapter will always receive a valid, unique identifier, ensuring Exactly Once delivery for your IDoc outbound scenarios.

Configuration Options

As mentioned earlier, both the IDoc receiver connection parameters and the IDoc control header can be configured dynamically at runtime. The IDoc Receiver Adapter offers several supported options for this, as described in the SAP Help documentation - and these options can be freely combined. You can define connection parameters and control header values in multiple places:

  • In the scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07):
    • Connection parameters can be maintained as message headers.
    • The IDoc control record can be defined directly in the message body through a mapping. Alternatively, you can set specific control record fields as message headers and instruct the Generic IDoc Outbound flow (Step 08) to overwrite the corresponding control record fields with the values provided in Step 07.
  • In the Partner Directory.
  • In the generic IDoc outbound integration flow (Step 08), if you choose to configure parameters directly there.

We differentiate between two groups of configuration data:

  • IDoc Control Header Handling. By default, we assume that the control header is already present in the message body produced by the scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07). If you want to override specific fields in the control header, you must explicitly specify which fields should be overwritten at runtime.
  • IDoc Adapter Connection Parameters Handling. You have two approaches:
    • Receiver-specific IDoc Outbound flow (copy of Step 08 for each receiver):
      Copy the Cloud Integration Pipeline – Generic Outbound package and create dedicated generic IDoc outbound flows per Receiver System. In this case, the connection parameters are exposed as externalized parameters of each copied Step 08 flow.
    • One single generic IDoc Outbound flow (shared Step 08):
      Use a single shared generic IDoc outbound flow across all IDoc scenarios and IDoc receiver systems. Here, connection parameters are maintained either in the Partner Directory or as message headers in the scenario-specific outbound flow.

Sample Scenario

This blog post aims to walk you through these configuration options using sample scenarios. In the Partner Directory, we have prepared three example configuration setups that cover all supported combinations. To keep the examples simple, we use IDoc-to-IDoc pass-through scenarios - bulk IDoc messages are sent to the generic IDoc inbound flow on the sender side, and the generic IDoc outbound flow on the receiver side. No mapping is applied; depending on the scenario, we either keep the bulk message or split it into individual IDocs. This way the IDoc control header on the receiver side is already set and we can demonstrate how specific fields can be selectively overridden.

Option 1: Message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow

For the first configuration scenario, we use the first option by maintaining message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow.

For both the sender system and the receiver system we need to define a partner ID representing the business systems in order to map from the actual system names to the alias names. Within the pipeline, we work with alias names to be independent of the system landscape. As an example, the screenshot below shows the partner ID of the sender system with the alias name BS_06C_S1. In the Alternative Partners tab, we map the actual names to the alias depending on the landscape stage, e.g., for QA the actual business system name is BS_06C_S1Q and the actual logical system name is C6QCLNT608. If you like to know more about how to setup the support for different landscape stages, check out Landscape Stages.

On the Alternative Partners tab of the configuration scenario (here: CS_PIP_Samples_Scenario_06C), we map the sender system name and the sender interface name to the configuration scenario. The sender interface name is a combination of the Message Type and the IDoc basic type (and optional extension), see IDoc Sender Adapter.

On the String Parameters tab, we maintain the receiver and interface configuration. This represents the Point-to-Point special case described in Pipeline Bypass Options. In Point-to-Point scenarios, no XSLT is needed for receiver or interface determination. Instead:

  • The parameter receiverDetermination is set to the alias of the receiver system.
  • The parameter interfaceDetermination is set to the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07), using the alias name as suffix.

Based on the configured KeepBulk setting, the IDoc bulk is not split within the pipeline (by generic Inbound Processing for Idoc).

The ProcessDirect endpoint configured in the scenario-specific outbound flow matches the one referenced in the Partner Directory configuration.

In the scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07), a Content Modifier maintains the IDoc control record fields and IDoc adapter connection parameters as message headers. These headers are then forwarded to the Generic IDoc Outbound flow (Step 08).

To override selected IDoc control headers, the header SAP_IDoc_EDIDC_overrideControlRecordParameters must be set. This header contains a comma-separated list of the control record fields to be overwritten.

For configuring the IDoc receiver adapter, we maintain the IDoc content type, credential alias, authentication method, proxy type, and the IDoc endpoint of the receiver system. Detailed parameter naming and patterns are described in the IDoc Receiver Adapter documentation.

The scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07) calls the Generic IDoc Outbound flow (Step 08) via a ProcessDirect adapter. 

The default endpoint of the generic flow is: /generic/step08/idoc. You may adjust this to your own naming conventions; in our scenario, we kept the default.

Finally, we sent a sample IDoc bulk message through the pipeline. In the Message Monitor, all processing steps belonging to the same message can be viewed by selecting the Correlation ID. In the Properties and Custom Headers sections, you will find the relevant runtime information, including:

  • Actual sender and receiver names
  • Interface name
  • Full list of IDoc numbers in the bulk message (we kept bulk on inbound and outbound). It is possible to set a custom header for each individual IDoc, or to combine all IDoc numbers from a bulk message into a single header containing an array of values
  • IDoc sender and receiver partner values
  • IDoc control headers that were overridden

Option 2: Parameters in the Partner Directory

The second configuration scenario uses the second option, where Partner Directory parameters are maintained. The scenario-specific outbound processing flow is configured with a ProcessDirect endpoint in the configuration scenario, similar to the approach described in the previous chapter.

Although the actual control header values are configured in the Partner Directory, we must still define the header SAP_IDoc_EDIDC_overrideControlRecordParameters in the scenario. This header lists the control fields that should be overridden.

As in the previous option, the message is forwarded to the generic IDoc outbound flow using the default endpoint.

As mentioned earlier, both the IDoc control headers and the connection parameters can be maintained in the Partner Directory. For the connection parameters, we define a partner ID that represents the business system. This is required to map the actual business system name to its alias. In our example, the alias is BS_06A_R1.
On the String Parameters tab of the alias, we maintain the IDoc connection parameters - IDoc Content Type, Proxy Type, Authentication Method, Credential Alias, and IDoc Endpoint of the receiver system. The naming convention is to append the actual system name as a suffix to each parameter. In this example, parameters are defined for QA and PRD only; typically you would maintain parameters for all landscapes. Since this business system alias can be shared across multiple configuration scenarios, the connection settings can be reused.

The IDoc control headers are scenario-specific and therefore maintained as string parameters directly on the configuration scenario (scenario partner id). These parameters must be defined per receiver interface. To do this, add the receiver interface name as a suffix. The default receiver interface name consists of the message type, IDoc type, and optionally the extension. However, this receiver interface name suffix is configurable with a message header SAP_IDoc_EDIDC_pidParameterReadSuffixPattern from Step 07 or using Externalized Parameter of the Step 08 (default value is MESTYP.IDOCTYP.CIMTYP). For detailed parameter names, refer to IDoc Receiver Adapter.

Because no KeepBulk parameter is defined here, the default behavior applies: the IDoc bulk is split by generic Inbound Processing for Idoc (Step 01), and individual IDocs are processed separately in the pipeline.

After sending a sample message to the pipeline, you can monitor the processed messages in the message monitor. Since the IDoc bulk is split into two individual messages, two IDoc messages are sent out, and you will see two corresponding logs from the generic IDoc outbound flow.

 

Option 3: Configuring the generic IDoc outbound integration flow

The third configuration scenario uses the third option: a receiver-specific generic IDoc outbound integration flow that can be reused across multiple scenarios. To implement this option, you need to create a copy of the generic IDoc outbound integration flow and expose the connection parameters as externalized parameters in the copied flow. It is important not to copy the integration flow directly. Instead, copy the standard package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound from the SAP Business Accelerator Hub. This ensures that your copied flow continues to receive updates. A more detailed explanation of this approach is provided in the blog for XI: Generic XI Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline.

In the copied package, configure the flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 – Outbound Processing for IDoc.
Before deploying the flow, you must assign a unique ProcessDirect endpoint, as endpoints must be unique within the tenant.

In addition, under the More tab, maintain the IDoc connection parameters and the default IDoc control headers. These values act as defaults and are only applied if no other values are provided.
In this pass-through scenario, the incoming IDoc already contains all control headers. Therefore, the only way to change control headers is to override them in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow (see below). In scenarios where the sender is not an IDoc sender, you may define the IDoc control headers directly here.

In the corresponding scenario-specific outbound processing flow, we maintain the list of IDoc control headers that should be overridden. As in the previous scenarios, this is done by defining the header SAP_IDoc_EDIDC_overrideControlRecordParameters, where the control fields to be overridden are provided as a comma-separated list.

To invoke the copied generic IDoc outbound flow, we specify its ProcessDirect endpoint as configured above.

After sending a sample IDoc bulk message to the pipeline, you can monitor the message processing in the message monitor. Note that in this scenario, the bulk is also preserved.

We hope this helps you set up your IDoc outbound scenarios using the new generic IDoc outbound flow of the Cloud Integration Pipeline. If you are missing any IDoc-specific processing capabilities that would be useful for such a generic IDoc receiver flow, feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Good to Know

The Outbound Processing for IDoc integration flow applies several basic validation rules:

  • Message body format: The message payload must be in XML format if you intend to override IDoc control headers.
  • Content type for non-bulk IDocs: If the ARCKEY field exists in the control record and the IDoc is not a bulk, then the content type must be Application/x-sap.idoc.
  • Content type for bulk IDocs: If the message is an IDoc bulk, then the content type must be Text/XML.
  • EOIO considerations (Exactly Once In Order). The pipeline framework does not support sequenced EOIO quality of service as of now. However, if you connect your own flow to the generic Outbound Processing for IDoc flow and pass the message header SapPlainSoapQoS = ExactlyOnceInOrder, then you must set ARCKEY in your caller flow. The generic Outbound Processing for IDoc flow cannot construct ARCKEY on your behalf (e.g., using patterns like urn:sap.com:seq=${header.SapQueueId}-${header.nextIDoc}-${header.Date} - as described in SAP Note 1613719).

Why IDoc Transmission Uses Request-Reply:

A frequent question concerns why all IDoc connections to the receiver are implemented using a Request-Reply step - i.e., why IDoc transmission is always synchronous and no asynchronous option exists.

  • IDoc over XML-HTTP is always synchronous.
    Technically, IDoc transmission via XML-HTTP is a synchronous web service call to /sap/bc/srt/IDoc in the backend system.
  • A full SOAP response is always returned.
    This response includes the IdocAssign structure, linking the TransferId with the DbId of the created or existing IDoc.
  • Idempotency behavior:
    • If an inbound IDoc with the same Message ID already exists, no new IDoc is created. Instead, the system returns the existing IDoc number in the SOAP response.
    • If the Message ID is new, the system creates an IDoc and returns the newly assigned IDoc number.

Because of this mandatory synchronous behavior, the use of Request-Reply is technically required and cannot be replaced by an asynchronous pattern (like Send step). At the same time, the SOAP response can be parsed, and custom headers containing the backend-assigned IDoc numbers are added to the MPL for tracking purposes by generic Outbound Processing for IDoc flow.

entry.title: The Future of Amusement Parks: How SAP Powers the Next Wave of Thrill & Technology
entry.content:
The Future of Amusement Parks: How SAP Powers the Next Wave of Thrill & Technology

When I attended the SAP Top Architect Bootcamp, I expected to deepen my understanding of SAP solutions—and I certainly did. But what surprised me was how often my thoughts drifted back to the world I live in every day: the amusement-park industry, where I’ve spent the past two years shaping experiences, studying operations, and watching how technology transforms guest expectations.

As a mother, my visits to theme parks with my son have also given me a unique, personal perspective. Watching his excitement, his curiosity, and how he interacts with attractions helped me see first-hand how the future of theme parks must evolve.

So, with every SAP capability I explored—across CX, analytics, BTP, AI, and sustainability—I couldn’t help but imagine: What would the theme park of the future look like for me and my son?

  1. Personalised Guest Experiences — The Magic of SAP CX

The Story Begins:

The moment my son and I scan our tickets, our park experience transforms.

My phone buzzes with a personalised route suggestion—highlighting shorter queues, shaded rest spots, and our favourite attractions. Meanwhile, my son receives a notification from his wearable wristband inviting him to meet his favourite character nearby. This hyper-personalised experience is powered by SAP CX.

  • Builds rich guest profiles for both adults and children, tailoring our journey. We can enhance the same using SAP Customer Data Platform - https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/customer-data-platform.html which seamlessly integrates into a 360° customer profile.
  • Sends AI-driven recommendations—like a quiet snack zone when kids need a break. This can be leverage with SAP Emarsys - https://www.sap.com/products/crm/emarsys.html  as  it offers personalised suggestions
  • Personalised bundles for families, child-specific deals, and dynamic pricing. This can be achieved  SAP Commerce Cloudhttps://www.sap.com/india/products/crm/commerce-cloud.html.
  • Smooth, intuitive interfaces across mobile and wearables. SAP Build Apps ( https://www.sap.com/india/products/technology-platform/low-code-app-builder.html) and Spartacus (https://community.sap.com/t5/crm-and-cx-blog-posts-by-members/introduction-to-spartacus/ba-p/13418581) can help us to build intuitive interfaces.

For families like ours, this means a day that feels designed just for us.

  1. Immersive AR/VR Worlds — Powered by SAP BTP

The Adventure Expands:

As my son and I stroll through the enchanted forest zone, he suddenly gasps. A digital dragon appears—hovering above us, reacting to his movements and responding to his excitement. He chases it playfully, and the AR storyline adapts in real time to his reactions.

That magic is orchestrated by SAP BTP:

  • Ensuring AR storytelling adapts to our real-world location . SAP Event Mesh can be used to achieve the same(https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite/capabilities/event-mesh.html)
  • Links my son’s wearable profile so the experience feels personal. SAP Integration Suite can be used for personalised and dynamic experience.(https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite.html)
  • Behind the scenes, analytics help the park understand which experiences engage you most, enabling continuous optimization of these immersive zones and this can be achieved by SAP Analytics Cloud (https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/cloud-analytics.html).    

These immersive experiences create unforgettable moments—for children and adults alike.

  1. Intelligent Park Operations — AI, IoT & Automation at Work

As my son and I enjoy our day, SAP technology silently ensures everything runs flawlessly.

  • Monitoring of ride safety in real time, giving parents like me peace of mind .SAP IoT(https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_IoT/fffd6ca18e374c2e80688dab5c31527f/3c61bd1bedc4473fbd952e92b5e7cf8d.html) sensors monitor ride performance in real time, ensuring that everything operates at peak performance.
  • Technicians use AR-guided repairs to minimize downtime which can be managed by SAP Field Service Management (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/field-service-management/what-is-field-service-management.html).
  • AI ensures enough staff are available at family-heavy zones. SAP SuccessFactors  - https://www.sap.com/india/products/hcm.html.
  • Streamlines operations so staff can focus on guest care. SAP Build Process Automation can be used for automating the manual processes.https://www.sap.com/india/products/technology-platform/process-automation/features.html

This invisible intelligence creates a smoother, safer experience—especially for families with young children.

  1. Sustainability at the Core — Enabled by SAP’s Green Solutions.

As we walk, I feel proud showing my son how the park embraces sustainability. Showing him recycling stations that are intelligently placed based on crowd flow, solar panels integrated into ride structures, and sustainable materials used in the food packaging and merchandise, enhance my son’s understanding of sustainability.

SAP can helps us to enable this shift by using products like 

  • SAP Sustainability Control Tower (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/sustainability-control-tower.html) for environmental analytics
  • SAP Responsible Design & Production  (https://www.sap.com/india/products/scm/responsible-design-and-production.html) for greener materials
  • SAP Waste Management  (https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_ERP/8a399f5444164440ac4f426e847ec901/7567bd534f22b44ce10000000a174cb4.html) powered by IoT.
  • SAP Green Ledger (https://www.sap.com/india/products/financial-management/green-ledger.html) tying sustainability to financial accountability.

This creates a park not just fun—but responsible.

  1. Data as the Heartbeat of the Connected Park

For families like mine, the magic is seamless—but behind the scenes, data orchestrates is everything. Every twist, turn, and laugh in the park is driven by data. You might not see the data at work, but it’s there, ensuring the best possible experience for you, every step of the way.

From real-time ride performance to the preferences of every guest, SAP can be used to unify data, ensuring that everything works in harmony.

SAP’s data-driven approach can be helpful every part of the park:

  • All guest and operational data is integrated into one foundation, enabling real-time, personalised experiences. SAP Datasphere ( https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/datasphere.html ) can be leverage for the same 
  • Systems like ticketing, AR/VR, and mobile apps needs to work seamlessly together to create a unified digital experience and this can be managed  by SAP Integration Suite (https://www.sap.com/products/technology-platform/integration-suite.html)
  • Predictive analytics help the park optimize everything from crowd flow to ride performance, ensuring an efficient and exciting day for all visitors. Here we can use SAP Analytics Cloud (https://www.sap.com/products/data-cloud/cloud-analytics.html) to help to do Predictive analytics.
  • Advanced AI models forecast guest behaviour, allowing the park to continuously enhance experiences and predict future trends. SAP AI Core (https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/serviceCatalog/sap-ai-core) can be leveraged for the same.

🌟 The Future of Fun, Built on SAP — For Families, For Dreamers, For Everyone

As my son and I leave the park, tired but smiling, I realise this is what the next generation of amusement parks must deliver—a world where operational excellence, cutting-edge technology, and deeply personal experiences collide.

entry.title: Calling SAP API Management from SAP Cloud Integration Using API Proxy URL & OAuth Authorization.
entry.content:
This guide explains how to connect SAP API Management (APIM) with SAP Cloud Integration (CPI) using an API Proxy URL secured by OAuth 2.0 authentication.

NorthWind Link: https://services.odata.org/northwind/northwind.svc/ 

1. Create API Provider.

2. Create API Proxy - To Generate an OAuth Authentication Token.

3. Add Policy - To generate OAuth 2.0 Authentication.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <Operation>GenerateAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/>
       <SupportedGrantTypes>
           <GrantType>client_credentials</GrantType>
       </SupportedGrantTypes>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

4. Create API Provider.

5. Add Policies to the API Proxy created to call the OData. 

Verify API Key - To verify the key which you are going to pass while calling the API.

<!--Specify in the APIKey element where to look for the variable containing the api key--> 
<VerifyAPIKey async='true' continueOnError='false' enabled='true' 
xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
	<APIKey ref='request.header.apikey '/>
</VerifyAPIKey>

OAuth 2.0 - To verify the OAuth Token generated.

<OAuthV2 async="false" continueOnError="false" enabled="true" xmlns="http://www.sap.com/apimgmt">
   <ExternalAuthorization>false</ExternalAuthorization>
   <!-- valid values are GenerateAccessToken, GenerateAccessTokenImplicitGrant, GenerateAuthorizationCode ,
    RefreshAccessToken , VerifyAccessToken , InvalidateToken , ValidateToken  -->
   <Operation>VerifyAccessToken</Operation>
   <GenerateResponse enabled="true"/><SupportedGrantTypes/>
   <Tokens/>
</OAuthV2>

Assign Message:

<!-- This policy can be used to create or modify the standard HTTP request and response messages -->
<AssignMessage async="false" continueOnError="true" enabled="true" xmlns='http://www.sap.com/apimgmt'>
    <Remove>   
     	<Headers>      
			<Header name="Authorization"></Header>   
          </Headers>
     </Remove> 
	<IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>true</IgnoreUnresolvedVariables>
	<AssignTo createNew="false" type="request"></AssignTo>
</AssignMessage>

Update >> Save >> Deploy

6. Create Product & Add both the API Proxies.

7. Create a Subscription for the Product created.

Copy the API URL, KEY and Secret for future use.

8. Create an Integration Flow.

Content Modifier: Pass Authentication Details in Header

  • client_secret: from the subscription 
  • client_id: from the subscription 
  • response_type: token
  • grant_type: client_credentials
  • Content-Type: application/x-www-form-urlencoded

Body: grant_type=${header.grant_type}&client_id=${header.client_id}&client_secret=${header.client_secret} 

Request Reply - HTTP 1: For Token Verification.

Content Modifier 2: For the Passing of Authorisation and API Key.

Content Modifier 3: Pass Bearer Token

Header: Bearer ${header.Access_Token_Value}

Request Reply - HTTP 2: Pass the endpoint URL of the API Proxy.

It's time to test.

For Token generation:

OAuth 2.0

Hit Send >> 200 OK

Debug >>

Trace:

The integration between SAP Cloud Integration and SAP API Management using OAuth 2.0 has been configured and tested successfully.

entry.title: Use Datastore to avoid too many duplicate MPL attachments in exception retries
entry.content:
Use Datastore to avoid too many duplicate MPL attachments in exception retries

 

 

Introduction:

This blog post demonstrates how to use DataStore to retain Source payload & Intermediate Payload for error handling.

Common Practice is to write the Source Payload and intermediate payload (inflight payload) into MPL attachment using groovy script.

 

Problem:

In general, for Asynchronous scenario retry mechanism is placed to resend the failed message until the issue is fixed. Sometimes we want flexibility on retry mechanism without placing restriction on fixed number of retries.

This flexibility helps Interface to automatically resend the failed messages when target connection is resolved without manual intervention or when we are waiting for a change to move to production then it should automatically process the failed message.

This flexibility comes at a cost of writing the payload into MPL attachment every time message goes into error/exception. This fills up limited Monitoring Storage. If your interface is retried 100 times at least 100/200 MPL attachments will be created in Message Monitoring. This Problem is exaggerated if we have high volume interface.

 

We generally use exception subprocess to log source payload as an attachment using groovy script which is helpful during error for debugging later.

 

Groovy Script.

 

/* Refer the link below to learn more about the use cases of script.

https://help.sap.com/viewer/368c481cd6954bdfa5d0435479fd4eaf/Cloud/en-US/148851bf8192412cba1f9d2c17f4bd25.html

 

If you want to know more about the SCRIPT APIs, refer the link below

https://help.sap.com/doc/a56f52e1a58e4e2bac7f7adbf45b2e26/Cloud/en-US/index.html */

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message;

 

 

def Message logExceptionPayloads(Message message) {                                      

    def body = message.getBody(String);

    def sourcePayload       = message.getProperties().get("sourcePayload");

    def exceptionMessage    = message.getProperties().get("exceptionMessage");

    def exceptionlogging    = message.getProperties().get("enableExceptionLog");

   

    if(exceptionlogging && exceptionlogging.equalsIgnoreCase("true")){

        def messageLog = messageLogFactory.getMessageLog(message);

       

        if(messageLog != null){

            messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("1.Exception Log", exceptionMessage, "text/xml");

            messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("1.Source Payload",sourcePayload,"text/xml");

            messageLog.addAttachmentAsString("2.Inflight Payload",body,"text/xml");

        }

    }

}

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

This creates lot of attachments for every run as we are attaching Source Payload, Inflight Payload and ExceptionLog based on the above groovy code.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Solution:

 

We were wondering if we can retain the flexibility of unrestricted message retries without the downside of so many attachments.

We stumbled upon the idea of utilizing datastore with override option to store the source payload and intermediate payload instead of MPL attachments using groovy script.

 

 

Above is the datastore approach where we are storing two payloads in Data Store.

  1. Intermediate or Inflight Payload- this is the transformed payload just before the error step
  2. Source Payload – Original Payload after entering the Integration flow.

 

set Exception Properties

 

 

 

 

 

Create errorDataStore Property  Error_${camelId} <Error_InterfaceID>

Create sourceMessage Property  SourcePayload_${header.SAP_MplCorrelationId}

Create inflightMessage Property InflightPayload_${header.SAP_MplCorrelationId}

 

We are appending SAP_MplCorrelationId header field for better search of failed message in datastore.

 

Write Inflight /Intermediate Payload

 

Write intermediate payload into data store as define in above Property errorDataStore

Give Datastore EntryID as  InflightPayload_${header.SAP_MplCorrelationId}

Make sure Overwrite Existing Message is checked. This will allow the same message to be overwritten in Datastore entry without creating multiple entries in case of multiple retries from JMS Queue.

 

 

 

 

 

get sourcePayload

 

get the source payload into the body which was stored in a sourcePayload Property using Content Modifier in the very first step of IntegrationFlow.

 

 

 

 

 

Write sourcePayload

Write the source payload into same datastore using Property errorDataStore with EntryID ${property.sourceMessage}. Make sure Overwrite Existing Message is checked. This will allow the same message to be overwritten in Datastore entry without creating multiple entries in case of multiple retries from JMS Queue.

 

 

 

 

 

 

Result

 

Datastore with only two entries are created even though we had 14 runs

 

 

 

 

 

 

Other Monitoring Observations

If the datastore entry for Retry message is deleted, then the status of the message in Monitoring will be changes to Cancelled, but this don’t prevent to re-create datastore again in next retry.

The status of the message in monitoring doesn’t revert to retry. This doesn’t prevent Message to keep retrying.  Once the issue is fixed and message status changes to Completed.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Once the message is successfully processed the status is changed to Completed

 

 

 

 

 

Later on, for successful messages you can remove the datastore entries by searching on correlation id which we have used to create EntryID. Alternative MPL ID ca also be used for cleanup.

 

Alternatively, APIs can also be used to automate to clean up data store entries on a scheduled basis. Below is the API reference.
